text: now there are intensified diplomatic
efforts to avert any conflict in ukraine
which is tens of thousands of russian
troops massed along the border french
president emmanuel macron he's going to
travel to moscow later on monday for
talks with vladimir putin mr macron says
the deal is still possible our
correspondent caroline davies has more
on the talks in moscow
i think the fact that there are still
some level of diplomatic talks going on
is of course incredibly important given
that there are there are rising tensions
about ukraine and as long as these
conversations keep going i think the
west feels like there is hope of what in
diplomatic terms is quite often called
an off-ramp a way of de-escalating this
situation but in terms of what we're
actually expecting from the meeting
between president putin and macron today
i don't think we're going to get some
form of absolute resolution that this
sort of situation will be completely
resolved but of course president macron
has been relatively positive about this
he's talked about the fact that he
thinks there is still the possibility of
a deal he's talked about the the fact
that it's uh it's legitimate for russia
to talk about its security concerns but
at the same time it's crucially
important to preserve the security and
the sovereignty of ukraine this is the
difficult balance that western leaders
are kind trying to strike at the moment
they're trying to keep russia at the
diplomatic table but at the same time
sound firm about what they need out of
the situation and has mr macron hinted
at all of what that possible deal might
look like
well i think we know a little bit about
what nato the us the west's uh stance is
towards russia about what it's willing
to negotiate on and what it's not to
start with what it's not uh it's of
course nato expansion now russia
president putin have made it very clear
that um one of their key security
demands is that they do not want nato to
expand any further they don't want any
more countries to join the nato alliance
but particularly they don't want ukraine
to join that alliance however the u.s
and nato have been absolutely adamant
that they don't want uh to have any
third country having a say over who gets
to join nato or not and they continue
with the open door policy so that is not
on the table however we do know that
there are certain things that the us did
suggest to russia um that was when they
provided their responses to the russia's
demands which were made back in december
if you can follow the timeline and some
of those elements include the sort of
discussions about missile deployment
about
checking missiles on both sides as well
these are all sort of lower level
confidence building measures
that i think the west is hoping that
russia might make some movement on
however we still haven't had a russian
response to those u.s responses about
exactly what they're planning to do next
uh they've talked about the importance
of continuing with diplomacy but at the
same time they've also said that the key
russian security demands were not
answered by the west at the moment so in
terms of where we're going to be able to
find some diplomatic solution it's still
not certain uh russia of course
continues to maintain that it has no
plans to invade ukraine
but in terms of where we get a
de-escalation we just don't know yet
